chapters.name: The Outsider: Youth and Education (1879-1905)
topics: Who was Albert Einstein before he changed physics — born in Ulm, Germany, the son of a failed electrical equipment manufacturer, a mediocre student who clashed with authority, a young man who renounced German citizenship at 16 and was stateless for five years?

Why did Einstein fail to get an academic position after graduating from the Zurich Polytechnic — rejected by every university he applied to, reduced to working as a patent clerk in Bern — and how did this isolation from the academic establishment actually free his thinking?

What was the 'Annus Mirabilis' of 1905 — four papers published in a single year that explained Brownian motion, proved the photoelectric effect, introduced special relativity, and derived E=mc² — all written by a 26-year-old patent clerk with no laboratory?

How did Einstein's personal life shape his early career — his relationship with Mileva Marić, their illegitimate daughter Lieserl (whose fate remains unknown), their marriage, and the question of Mileva's uncredited contribution to his early work?

What was the scientific world Einstein entered — classical physics seemingly complete, Newton's mechanics unchallenged for 200 years, the ether hypothesis, and the cracks (blackbody radiation, the Michelson-Morley experiment) that suggested something fundamental was wrong?

chapters.name: General Relativity and Scientific Revolution (1905-1919)
topics: How did Einstein develop the general theory of relativity over ten years (1905-1915) — the insight that gravity is not a force but the curvature of spacetime caused by mass — and why was this the most profound reconception of the universe since Newton?

What was the 1919 solar eclipse expedition — Arthur Eddington's measurement of starlight bending around the sun, confirming Einstein's prediction — and how did the headline 'Lights All Askew in the Heavens' make Einstein the most famous scientist in history overnight?

How did Einstein's rise to fame coincide with World War I — his pacifism as a German professor while colleagues signed war manifestos, his Swiss citizenship protecting him, and the irony that a British expedition confirmed a German theory just months after the armistice?

What did general relativity predict that seemed impossible — black holes, gravitational waves, the expansion of the universe, time dilation near massive objects — and how have these predictions been confirmed over the century since, culminating in LIGO's detection of gravitational waves (2015)?

Why did Einstein receive the Nobel Prize in 1921 not for relativity but for the photoelectric effect — because the Nobel committee considered relativity too controversial — and what does this reveal about how scientific establishments process revolutionary ideas?

chapters.name: Fame, Exile, and the Bomb (1919-1945)
topics: How did Einstein become the world's first celebrity scientist — mobbed by crowds, photographed constantly, asked his opinion on everything from God to marriage — and how did his disheveled appearance and quotable wit create the archetype of 'genius' that persists today?

Why did Einstein leave Germany in 1933 — the rise of the Nazis, the 'Deutsche Physik' movement that denounced relativity as 'Jewish physics,' his property seized, a bounty on his head — and how did Princeton's Institute for Advanced Study become his refuge?

What was Einstein's letter to President Roosevelt (August 2, 1939) — warning that Nazi Germany might develop an atomic bomb, urging American research into nuclear weapons — and how did the pacifist who wrote it spend the rest of his life regretting it?

How did the Manhattan Project develop without Einstein — his security clearance denied because the FBI considered him a security risk, his equation E=mc² underlying the bomb but his pacifism excluding him from building it — and what did he say when he heard about Hiroshima: 'Woe is me'?

What was Einstein's quantum mechanics debate with Niels Bohr — 'God does not play dice' versus the Copenhagen interpretation, the EPR paradox, Einstein's refusal to accept quantum indeterminacy — and was Einstein wrong, stubborn, or ahead of his time?

chapters.name: The Personal Einstein: Marriages, Children, and Character
topics: What was Einstein's first marriage to Mileva Marić — a brilliant physics student who gave up her career, endured his affairs, raised their sons largely alone, and received his Nobel Prize money as part of the divorce settlement (1919) — and how has feminist scholarship reexamined her contributions?

How did Einstein treat his sons — Hans Albert (who became an engineering professor at Berkeley) and Eduard (who developed schizophrenia and was institutionalized) — and what does his absence as a father, especially his abandonment of the ill Eduard, reveal about the cost of genius to those closest to it?

What was Einstein's second marriage to his cousin Elsa — who managed his domestic life, shielded him from intrusions, and tolerated his affairs — and why have biographers characterized this relationship as more practical arrangement than love match?

How did Einstein's personality combine opposites — warmth and coldness, humility and arrogance, deep compassion for humanity and emotional cruelty to individuals — and why did he write that 'I have never belonged wholeheartedly to any country or state, to my circle of friends, or even to my own family'?

What was Einstein's relationship with music — his lifelong violin and piano playing, his claim that 'if I were not a physicist, I would probably be a musician,' his admiration for Mozart above all — and how did aesthetic intuition guide his scientific thinking?

chapters.name: Legacy: The Icon of Genius
topics: How did Einstein become an activist in his final decade — campaigning for nuclear disarmament, world government, civil rights (calling racism 'America's worst disease'), and socialism — applying the same independence of thought to politics that he had to physics?

What was Einstein's relationship with Israel — offered the presidency in 1952 (he declined), a lifelong Zionist who supported a Jewish homeland but opposed nationalism, and his warning that treating Palestinians unjustly would undermine the moral foundation of the state?

Why did Einstein spend his last 30 years pursuing a unified field theory — trying to reconcile gravity and electromagnetism into a single framework — and why did the physics community consider this quest a dead end while string theorists now pursue essentially the same goal?

How did Einstein die on April 18, 1955 — refusing surgery for an abdominal aortic aneurysm, saying 'I want to go when I want, it is tasteless to prolong life artificially' — and what happened when pathologist Thomas Harvey stole his brain without permission?

What is Einstein's legacy — not just E=mc² and curved spacetime, but the demonstration that a single mind, thinking independently, can overturn centuries of established science — and why does his image remain the universal symbol of genius?
